capsules_submitted.utterance: I'm not a fan of the character Filch from Harry Potter. He's always causing trouble and being quite mean to the students. I think he's just trying to cover up his own flaws by being strict all the time.
capsules_submitted.reply: exciting news! i've never met an adult before, can you tell me more about what that's like?

capsules_submitted.utterance: Vernon is an adult. I'm pretty sure about that.
capsules_submitted.reply: i like it! so, vernon is also an adult, just like filch.

capsules_submitted.utterance: I'm not sure I agree with the idea that being an adult automatically means you're old. I think it's a bit misleading, don't you? I mean, just because someone is considered an adult in terms of age doesn't necessarily mean they're old or set in their ways.
capsules_submitted.reply: cool! so, filch is also an adult, just like vernon.

capsules_submitted.utterance: Vernon is an adult, and I think that's a great thing - he's likely established in his career and has a good sense of stability.
capsules_submitted.reply: that makes my day! vernon and filch are both adults.

capsules_submitted.utterance: You know, I've noticed that the character of Filch in our school's history is often portrayed as a bit of an adult in a child's world. He's always so strict and serious, it's like he's trying to be a grown-up before his time. (SENTIMENT: AMUSED)

You know, I've noticed that the character of Filch in our school's history is often portrayed as a bit of an adult in a child's world. He's always so strict and serious, it's like he's trying to be a role model or something. But at the same time, his age makes him seem a bit...out of touch? I mean, who expects a 60-year-old man to be dealing with teenage drama and angst all day long? It's almost like he's stuck in a different era.
